concept.title: Quotations
concept.shortdesc: Formal quotations, cited as documentary evidence, are introduced by a colon and enclosed in quotation marks.

conbody.lq: The provision of the Constitution is: No tax or duty shall be laid on articles exported from any state.
conbody.p: Quotations grammatically in apposition or the direct objects of verbs are preceded by a comma and enclosed in quotation marks.
conbody.lq: I recall the maxim of La Rochefoucauld, Gratitude is a lively sense of benefits to come.
Aristotle says, Art is an imitation of nature.
conbody.p: Quotations of an entire line, or more, of verse, are begun on a fresh line and centered, but need not be enclosed in quotation marks.
conbody.lq: Wordsworth's enthusiasm for the Revolution was at first unbounded:
Bliss was it in that dawn to be alive, But to be young was very heaven!
conbody.p: Quotations introduced by that are regarded as in indirect discourse and not enclosed in quotation marks.
conbody.lq: Keats declares that beauty is truth, truth beauty.
conbody.p: Proverbial expressions and familiar phrases of literary origin require no quotation marks.
conbody.lq: These are the times that try men's souls.
He lives far from the madding crowd.
conbody.p: The same is true of colloquialisms and slang.
